title: The Futurists - EPS_284: AI is for Artists with Bay Raitt

rawLines.text: when it starts to become physical when
robots start to actually do your laundry
and and build the products and do things
and free up time that we will have as a
society come up with a way to talk about
automation so that we can actually take
the profits of Automation and use it to
pay for the the livelihoods of the
displaced workers and make Society
better
[Music]
hey there welcome back to the futurist
I'm Rob Turk and my co-host Brett King
once again is Airborne someplace in the
Middle East so we won't be able to get
him on the call today but I do have a
really special guest somebody I've
wanted to bring on the show for some
time you know ever since we started
doing this program uh there's been this
debate raging about artificial
intelligence actually several different
debates about artificial intelligence
but one of the ones that keeps popping
up is that somehow AI is a threat to
artists or it's steal in from artists or
something like that listeners to the
show will recall that we've had a couple
of attorneys on the call a copyright
experts um Amir gavi who is happening
happens to defend a couple of the AI
companies in the litigation that's
happening right now the copyright
infringement litigation and we also had
Peter chotti who is a very outspoken
proponent for the rights of copyright
holders and he and I had a lively debate
both live in New York on stage and also
on the show uh so I've heard kind of
both sides of the legalistic debate but
then I thought about it more I was like
what I really want to do is talk to
somebody who's using AI as an artist and
who doesn't think it's totally evil in
the end of the world but in fact maybe
opening a new chapter for Creative
expression and that's why I decided to
invite on the show Bay rate ba welcome
to the futurist buddy hey good to see
you man it's great to see you thank you
for joining us thanks for making time to
do this um so on this show what we love
to do is talk about the future we want
to talk to you not only as an artist as
a technologist as an innovator but also
somebody who's shaping the future in
your work and I thought what we might do
as a starting point is talk about what
you've done uh you know like your career
because I think it's so interesting one
of the things I noticed B is um you and
I both had similar careers in a sense
that we've lived through these
transitions or Transformations every
decade or so it seems like the media
Universe goes through another gation and
it turns out to be something different
uh something maybe better uh certainly
faster bigger and
more participatory in some respects
because it's all on a network now and I
thought why don't we do that real
quickly like let's just take a a
snapshot of some of your career
highlights uh you started your career in
comic books in the 80s and 90s right
yeah I like to joke that I have the
dream job of every 14-year-old um I've
been really lucky in the sense that I've
got to work at the top of comics the top
of games the top of movies and VFX and
the top of tools in Tech um I uh I was
really lucky as a teenager I got a job
working for Steve Olaf at o opics on the
early image comic books so I worked on
um spawn and the pit and the Max and
Aira and some Batman books I was just a
a junior kid everybody there was Titans
I was just you know the the Newbie in
the corner but you know those were on
really old computers typing in cmk
values and sending them to Todd
McFarland's Uncle Tony to print them out
and making the very first like High
color glossy comics and using the very
first uh you know Photoshop to color a
comic book kind of back when it was
brand new I was one of those guys again
I was I was a kid in the room there was
a bunch of amazing people but then after
that I was really lucky I got to work on
the very first motion capture uh uh live
to tape children's television stuff so
like you put on a mocap suit and perform
a TV show I I helped build those
characters and built the first VR
characters and then after that I went
and worked uh and I built Gollum face
for the Lord of the Rings movies down in
New Zealand at WETA and I actually
designed and built the uh the software
that I made with a big team of people
who had actually invented computer
Graphics sort of field uh from the
symbolics.com which was the first URL on
the web I found like the old gry beard
Geniuses in the mountains and we all
built a tool together and that's what I
actually used to build gollum's face and
help set up the creature department and
the crowd Department the Ming department
at WETA and then I went and worked at
the WETA Workshop as a concept artist
and a sculptor so I'm like the weird
unicorn that's not supposed to exist I I
write code but I also draw and sculpt
and animate and and direct and so uh I
went from there and I went to work at UH
at valve for nine years and I worked on
a movie making tool called The Source
Filmmaker which is a movie making tool
built inside of valve's game engine I
also and for people are listening valve
is a major game publisher if you if
you're not familiar with the game
business so you you went to a game
company and helped them make movies yeah
and and basically I also worked on their
games but I was I work on a game called
Team Fortress 2 which we discovered uh
in kind of by accident this really
amazing way to collaborate with the
crowd we had 130 million people
connected directly to our offices and we
were basically selling hats virtual
items inside the game and we would
feature those hats in our in our shorts
and the community just was went berserk
making and contributing back to the
universe in something that I helped set
up called the Steam Workshop so you
basically had the sort of virtuous cycle
between the Creator and the audience and
I sort of got hooked on that and I've
since then I've worked at Unity I've
I've I've shipped uh VR titles um that
I've written myself and also with it
with with with amazing Crews um but
basically like you know I can make a
game by myself leave me alone with a
room and a computer and I can make you
movies games Comics tools and and Tech
and I've unlike a lot of people in the
AI space I've actually generated my own
training data either by hand or as as a
procedural artist using geometry nodes
and other procedural means generating
synthetic data sets uh I've also hired
map people and artists to make data sets
that I've then curated labeled and train
myself with with with my colleagues um
and so I have like a a pretty deep
knowledge
of what this landscape really is and so
a lot there's hang on S sec I want to
unpack that last one because people I
might have gone soaring past some of the
listeners so what you're saying there is
um in a way you're refuting one of the
claims that the people who are against
AI often say which is they'll say well
AI generative AI depends on the work of
artists and um it can only exist if it
steals the art from artists and it has
no value without that and what what I'm
hearing you say is well no in fact
there's a lot of ways to engage with
generative Ai and train a model and that
can include creating your own art or
training it on your own work or you can
commission original works and train it
on that in other words there are ethical
approaches I think it's important to
break that out because I had another
guest on the show make that exact claim
and at the time I thought that claim was
pretty feeble but I didn't get really a
chance to refute it so now here I can do
it I refute it a little bit more
resoundingly well there's two sides of
it right because on the one hand
you can train a model entirely off of
your own data but if you don't have a
critical mass of enough data the model
doesn't behave in this sort of magical
way that we associate with Gen um and so
to get it to to a critical mass where it
starts to actually do surprising things
you have to get it Across the Threshold
so to speak and so you can train a model
that's a refinement on top of a much
bigger model underneath but those big
models they're called Foundation models
they're they're essentially you know
between six gigabytes and and 90
gigabytes files of numbers they don't
actually contain any of the training
data they just contain weights and and
what they do is they behave kind of like
a Moog synthesizer where as you modulate
noise literally random noise like Cloud
bursting a cloud it will kind of
magnetically pull towards things that
are a mixture of a thousand things that
are kind of like what you might be
asking for and and and so those are the
things where the the voices of the past
of antiquity of of the last 5050 years
of digital media every every piece of
text everything that was public on the
web that got transferred over tcpip got
all those packets got used to train a
weight so it's not just artists it's
every you know security camera on the
outside of a building being transcribed
for whatever happened that day uh every
book written in every language you know
if you ask a medical question in Spanish
it goes and looks at all the medical
textbooks in Spanish and it answers in
Spanish so if you ask or it doesn't go
and look at them it's just referring to
the weight the stuff that yeah it's like
you're rolling a metal marble across a a
a billiard table full of magnets and the
and your metal marble swings around
based on those magnets until it gets to
stasis and then that's the result you
get and so it's not the result of one
single thing that it copied it's
actually a a mixture of everything and
by mean trillions of things yeah I think
that's an important point to make so uh
um the distinction you're making here
now is there are no copies of pictures
or songs or books there's no copies
inside of a generative AI model it's not
like a big scanning system uh or some
sort of library or database uh in other
words the metaphor was explained to me
which I thought was quite good they said
imagine that you are the world's
greatest detective and you're asked to
go through the Louver museum museum and
Define each painting in such a way that
it's like you know empirically
measurable and you would go through and
measure every brush stroke and the kinds
of colors you calibrate each the coast
until you get to so much data that you
can actually distinguish like you know a
van go or an impressionist painting from
something like a Dutch Master or
something that was done in the like um
in the in the medieval period uh that
you would have uh You' have calibrated
your your measurements so accurately
that those styles could be represented
mathematically and that's a claim that
they're making about uh generative AI I
mean we have to speak in metaphors but
when you get in the copyright Zone
you're always talking to met metaphor I
have a different metaphor which is like
there's a contrary metaphor what it's
not and and then a metaphor for what it
is and I I I like to point out that it's
not a pile of stolen documents that some
some device is going back and retrieving
and bringing to you it's more like a
constellation a Starfield of a galaxy of
weights and you're beaming a spaceship
into that weights and whatever it's near
has little gravity Wells and they pull
you towards things and so things that
are really common and cliche and trit
are like neutron stars they're like
black yeah they have a lot of gravity
they suck you towards the the the the
symmetrical head or that's that's why
everything you generate on Mid Journey
looks like it came from a game the cover
of the game the first result is always
the cliche and so when you ask it a
question you have to know like hey
you've just discovered your front
doorstep but there's a wide openen world
in there and the thing is that it is the
eus of humanity it's everything that's
ever been recorded and so when you start
to ask different questions and how you
ask matters you'll start to navigate
into really strange undiscovered
countries of the past and they're not
copies they're like weird blurry
hallucinations and I think that there's
I think of it like a super collaboration
with the past that you're you're
harmonizing with the past and you are
it's like a trifecta of collaboration
there's your intention as an artist
there's the the control of the tool that
you're using and interfacing with like a
mid Journey or a Chain of Thought or an
agentic workflow or something or the llm
uh and then there's Antiquity and those
three things are the collaborators and
Antiquity is millions if not billions of
people and and so when people start

protect artists like myself because
gollum's in all these models and and my
work is in there and if you say old man

stuff in that zone I can't lay 100%

like a trumpet player playing a trumpet
it's like well you can play a trumpet
long enough and eventually make it sound

where the the the labels start to get
really confusing is is people start to
see like hey there's this if I say Andy

it's seen all of the tutorials on how to

say Campbell soup soup can in a

copyright only covers creative

same is true with artistic style you

some people complain about that because

mod
